The Spectacular Now (2013)

Directed By: James Ponsoldt

Written By: Michael H. Weber

Tim Tharp's unsentimental tale of adolescent frustration comes to the screen in this comedy drama following the story of a sociable high school senior whose self-delusion shattered by his emerging friendship with an unpopular classmate.

TY Burr:  The festival’s opening night presentation comes to Boston after going over big at SXSW and especially Sundance, where costars Miles Teller and Shailene Woodley shared a special jury prize for “rare honesty, naturalism and transparency.” Translation: The movie’s a teenage romance with characters who seem like actual teenagers. Based on a novel by Tim Tharp, “Now” stars Teller (“Rabbit Hole”) as a life-of-the-party senior whose bravado masks insecurity; Woodley (“The Descendants”) is the class nobody he dates first out of pity and then — oh, you know. It’s an oft-told tale — a dab of John Hughes, a dash of “Perks of Being a Wallflower” — made fresh by the gentle realism of the playing and the levelheaded direction of James Ponsoldt (“Smashed”).

Rotten Tomatoes:  86%

As this is opening night of the Boston Independent Film Festival, I strongly encourage you to purchase your tickets in advance to avoid getting stuck in the Rush Line.

Opening Night has annually been among the funnest film events of the year.  According to Chase Whale, The Spectacular Now is "The most important adult-oriented film about the victories and woes of high school life in the last decade."

Opening Night can be a chaotic seating event.  Seating is likely to begin around 7:00 for Pass Holders, but the line for ticket holders starts forming around 6:15, and is well around the block by 6:45.  We gather at Mr. Crepe in Davis Square, next to the Somerville Theater, starting at around 6 to enjoy a bite to eat and to get into the line, together, when it begins to form for real, usually between 6:20 and 6:30.
